data.text:
"Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely. Great men are almost always bad men." ~John Dalberg-Acton. One in power can make into a drug, the taste of power can make one obsessed, and soon addicted. In the book “Night” by Elie Wiesel, two characters, Idek and Franek both represent the quote about power leading to corruption. Idek was a Jew that worked for the Nazi’s, he had some power and that corrupted his mind because later on, he started to beat other jews. The other character in Night, Franek, even though he did not have that much political power he had the power to manipulate others and gain himself privileges. The power these people have tends to be corrupted because it goes to their heads, they think they're above others, and that they’re capable to control others. Any type of power goes straight to people's heads, it consumes one’s mind and makes one do impeccable things. For example, in the novel “Night” by Elie Wiesel the character Idek was a jew who worked for the Nazis. He acted as though he was a Nazi and thought he can harm his own kind. He was Elie’s foreman who took advantage of the power he had. He uses his power to make Elie give him his gold crown. He wanted it so he would be able to use it for himself. He accomplished this by being kind to Elie until the crown soon became of no more value to him. Clearly, Franek was corrupted by the power he had. Franek was also tormented by the power Elie had, “‘If you don’t give me your crown, it will cost you much more!’ All of a sudden, this pleasant and intelligent young man had changed. His eyes were shining with greed” (55). Franek was at a state where his power was uncontrollable, once he didn’t get what he wanted he began to threaten Elie once again.
